etymology.description: 艹 (cǎo, "plant") + 因 (yīn, phonetic) = plant wrapped around or resembling something -> mattress/cushion
etymology.interpretation: The character combines the plant semantic 艹 (cǎo, "plant") with the phonetic component 因 (yīn) to convey the idea of a mat made of grass or plants, suggesting lushness or softness.

examples.chinese: 他坐在柔软的茵上(他坐在柔軟的茵上)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuò zài róu ruǎn de yīn shàng.
examples.english: He sits on a soft mat.

examples.chinese: 小院里铺着翠绿的茵(小院裡鋪著翠綠的茵)，欢迎归来的客人(歡迎歸來的客人)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎo yuàn lǐ pū zhe cuì lǜ de yīn, huān yíng guī lái de kè rén.
examples.english: A small courtyard is laid with verdant mats, welcoming the returning guests.

examples.chinese: 诗人于月下铺开茵(詩人於月下鋪開茵)，感叹岁月静好(感嘆歲月靜好)。
examples.pinyin: Shī rén yú yuè xià pū kāi yīn, gǎn tàn suì yuè jìng hǎo.
examples.english: The poet spreads out the mat under the moon, lamenting the peaceful passage of time.
